data.title: git partial staging not working
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open a modified file in git working tree
2. select some changed lines
3. from the `...` menu (top right) select "Stage selected ranges"

It shows an error

> Git: Illegal value for `line`

And in the output console panel:

```
Using git 2.12.2.windows.2 from C:\Program Files\Git\cmd\git.exe
git rev-parse --show-toplevel
git fetch
git config --get commit.template
git status -z -u
git symbolic-ref --short HEAD
git rev-parse master
git rev-parse --symbolic-full-name --abbrev-ref master@{u}
fatal: no upstream configured for branch 'master'

git for-each-ref --format %(refname) %(objectname)
git remote --verbose
git status -z -u
git symbolic-ref --short HEAD
git rev-parse master
git rev-parse --symbolic-full-name --abbrev-ref master@{u}
fatal: no upstream configured for branch 'master'

git for-each-ref --format %(refname) %(objectname)
git remote --verbose
git show HEAD:.../package.json
```

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Substitute variables in launch configuration keys (and not only in values)
data.body:
<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1  
- OS Version: Win7  

Feature description：
It would be nice to use the environment variable $ {env: variable} in launch.json sourceFileMap, like using the built-in variable $ {workspaceRoot}.  

The present situation is that we can write $ {env: variable} in sourceFileMap, but it is not replaced by real path like $ {workspaceRoot}.  

So, when debugging with cpptools extension for c++ program，vscode pops up the following message box:
```
Error: Unable to open 'main.cpp': File not found (\usr1\pDTest\demo\main.cpp). Create File Cancel
```

The sourceFileMap is very simple:   
```
"sourceFileMap": {
    // "remote": "local"
    
    // This way works well
    // "/usr1/pDTest/demo" : "D:\\demo"
    
    // This way does not work
    "/usr1/{env:USERNAME}/demo" : "D:\\demo"
},
```
This feature is useful for collaborative development of multiple programmers. we can push launch.json on git repo, and do not need everyone to modify it.

data.title: java syntax highlight break on annotation interface

data.title: Encode platform requirement in configuration
data.body:
To support better settings search, we need to produce a json file of all settings in a particular vscode build. To do this I'm starting Code in a mode where it will retrieve all configuration details from the ConfigurationRegistry and write them out. But some settings are only registered on certain platforms or OS versions. e.g. https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/electron-browser/main.contribution.ts#L365

I want to change this so that these settings are still known by the configuration registry, so we can retrieve them along with their platform requirements, but are still disabled/hidden when not on a supported platform. Otherwise, windows-only settings would be excluded if the file is produced on a Mac. 

I will try to come up with a PR proposal, but I'm open to suggestions @aeschli or @bpasero?

data.title: Add optional CompletionContext to provideCompletionItems
data.body:
Handles the completion item provider part of #752

Adds a new overload of `provideCompletionItems` that takes a context argument. This context is currently used to provide the trigger character of the suggestion

Part of #21543

data.title: cannot attach remote node process
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04.3 LTS (xenial)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Host a simple hello world node.js app on a remote machine (ip: `a.b.c.d`)
2. Start app with this command: `$ node --inspect=0.0.0.0:9229`
3. Configure vscode to attach remote process. Here is `launch.json`:

```
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "type": "node",
            "request": "attach",
            "name": "remote debug",
            "address": "ws://a.b.c.d/bde3bbb8-410d-48ca-949e-a1e07980882f",
            "port": 9229,
            "localRoot": "/home/xaqron/remote-debug",
            "remoteRoot": "/home/xaqron/remote-debug",
            "sourceMaps": true,
            "protocol": "inspector",
            "restart": true
        }
    ]
}
```

vscode stuck trying to connect.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Note: Using Google chrome I'm able to attach the remote node process (chrome://inspect).

data.title: [scss] Wrong autocomplete for build function in scss
data.body:
I write in scss file:
```
.example {
color: darken
}
```
after write darken I hit `tab` key to select value from autosuggest list, and finally i get:
```
color: darken(: , : 0)
```
instead of:
```
color: darken($color , $amout);
```
This same situation I have in all build functions, like for example:
```
str-index(: "", : "s")
str-length(: "")
nth(: , : )
```

data.title: Intellisense should put more weight on local objects
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

JavaScript intellisense has a lot of objects available via global scope and the various APIs available. While those options are good, I believe intellisense should give more weight to locally defined/imported objects & functions and display those at the top of the list.

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise 1511

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a basic app using something like create-react-app
2. Create a file `WorkerActions.js` that `export const WorkerActions = () => true;`
3. Within `App.js`, add `import {WorkerActions} from "./WorkerActions"`
4. Somewhere in the code, type `WA` and activate intellisense, notice that a bunch of WebAPI stuff pops up and `WorkerActions` is far down the list, beneath items like `WaveSharperNode` and `WebGLActiveInfo`

Example:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1666933/30230211-48afd81c-94b3-11e7-8f99-ae676b18e46d.png)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Allow extensions to override command title and/or icon in menu placement (in package.json)
Order of root folders is inconsistent when there are more than 10 root folders in a multi root workspace
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (aed2c7cc5c6ab2a092e524a59f82d17fc9348fc0, 2017-09-08T10:13:13.694Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0
- Extensions: Extensions are disabled
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a `test.code-workspace` workspace file with the following
```
{
  "folders": [
{
  "folders": [
    {"path": "0"},
    {"path": "1"},
    {"path": "2"},
    {"path": "3"},
    {"path": "4"},
    {"path": "5"},
    {"path": "6"},
    {"path": "7"},
    {"path": "8"},
    {"path": "9"},
    {"path": "10"}
  ],
	"settings": {}
}
```
2. The order of root folders in the multi root workspace is not as expected:
![screen shot 2017-09-08 at 1 29 21 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/760204/30230120-beffdca2-9499-11e7-861c-8f52398edc83.png)

With more root folders, the order is completely unpredictable, but always consistent.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: vscode-insiders replaced my user-settings with workspace settings
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: Version 1.17.0-insider (1.17.0-insider) (aed2c7cc5c6ab2a092e524a59f82d17fc9348fc0)
- OS Version: Sierra 10.12.6

Downloaded the latest vscode-insiders. I have two projects open, both with user setting and workspace settings (one is a notes folder, the other is a js project). 

Suddenly, the screen blipped and brought my mini-map back and reduced the font size. When I checked what happened, my user-settings globally had been replaced with my workspace settings 

```
{
  "workbench.colorCustomizations": {
    "statusBar.background": "#78dce8",
    "statusBar.noFolderBackground": "#78dce8",
    "statusBar.debuggingBackground": "#78dce8"
  },
  "vim.disableAnnoyingNeovimMessage": true,
  "workbench.iconTheme": "Monokai Pro (Filter Spectrum) Icons"
}
```

I wish I had been better about saving my user settings :( I don't think I can get them back, unfortunately.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Hang then crash by typing \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\ in integrated terminal
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.0 (787b31c0474e6165390b5a5989c9619e3e16f953, 2017-09-06T16:12:42.401Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
beautify|Hoo|1.1.1
vscode-docker|Pet|0.0.16
code-settings-sync|Sha|2.8.3
vscode-eslint|dba|1.3.0
tslint|eg2|1.0.1
cpptools|ms-|0.12.3
autoimport|ste|1.2.2
react-beautify|tai|0.3.0
vim|vsc|0.10.0
ReactSnippets|xab|1.4.0

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open integrated terminal
2. Type \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\

All of vscode will immediately hang. You will not be able to use any of the UI.
After a while it will show a macOS dialog "The window is no longer responding" with options to Close/Keep Waiting/Reopen.

This will happen regardless of whether the current working directly is a git repository or not.

Using a mid 2015 MacBook Pro.

Using zsh terminal with oh-my-zsh framework. It is not possible to reproduce this issue in a regular terminal, either macOS Terminal.app or iTerm.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: **Yes**/No

data.title: [Question] workspaceFolders behavior
data.body:
The description of the current `vscode.workspace.workspaceFolders` API is:
> List of workspace folders or undefined when no folder is open. Note that the first entry corresponds to the value of rootPath.

Why is it set to `undefined` and not simply an empty array when no folder is open ? This is the way `vscode.workspace.textDocuments` work if I'm not mistaken. I think it would make more sense to have the same behavior for both, and it wouldn't require always checking if `vscode.workspace.workspaceFolders` is defined or not before using it, while still clearly indicating when no folder is open.

Maybe there is a reason for this that I am not aware of, but it bugs me that those two APIs seemingly behave differently while doing the same kind of work.

- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-docker|Pet|0.0.16
ActiveFileInStatusBar|Ros|1.0.3

githistory|don|0.2.3
python|don|0.7.0

jsonnet|hep|0.0.13
Go|luk|0.6.65

Ruby|reb|0.15.0

vscode-proto3|zxh|0.1.2



---
I believe this regression happened about 2 versions ago:
It used to be the case that I could go to definitions directly from the right hand pane of the diff editor (ie, from the pane that represents the _current_ version of the file).  This is no longer the case. This seems to affect both languages that I regularly use: Java and Go

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No
N/A -- with disable-extensions, go to definition is not available.

data.title: Clean up from _readIsISOKeyboard change
data.body:
We should see how the new electron version works with regards to the ISO keyboard remapping and if things are OK we can delete that code on our end.

For now I pushed a change that will always return false for the call to `_readIsISOKeyboard`
